title: Visualization of Loss Functions
text: VisualizerLossFunction class visualizes loss functions. Loss functions wrapped LossFunction objects. package includes predefined loss functions used classification regression. get loss function dictionary, use lss() function. Many loss functions support parameters (e.g., quantile pinball loss, delta Huber loss, epsilon epsilon-insensitive loss). can specify parameters directly lss() function call. retrieve pinball loss function regression custom quantile parameter.
code: library(vistool) as.data.table(dict_loss) #> Key: <key> #>                     key                    label task_type #>                  <char>                   <char>    <char> #>  1:              cauchy              Cauchy Loss      regr #>  2:       cross-entropy                 Log Loss   classif #>  3: epsilon-insensitive Epsilon-Insensitive Loss      regr #>  4:               hinge               Hinge Loss   classif #>  5:               huber               Huber Loss      regr #>  6:               l1_ae        L1 Absolute Error      regr #>  7:               l2_se         L2 Squared Error      regr #>  8:         log-barrier         Log-Barrier Loss      regr #>  9:            log-cosh            Log-Cosh Loss      regr #> 10:             pinball             Pinball Loss      regr loss_function <- lss("pinball", quantile = 0.3)

title: Visualization of Loss Functions
text: visualize loss function, use as_visualizer() function. y_pred arguments contains y−f(x)y - f(x) (regression losses) y_true true value yy. default, loss functions plotted 1000 points smooth curves. Use plot() method plot loss function.
code: vis <- as_visualizer(loss_function, y_pred = seq(-4, 4), y_true = 0) vis$plot()

title: Visualization of Loss Functions
code: loss_huber = lss("huber") loss_l2 = lss("l2_se") loss_l1 = lss("l1_ae") loss_logcosh = lss("log-cosh")  vis_combined = VisualizerLossFuns$new(   list(loss_huber, loss_l2, loss_l1, loss_logcosh),   y_pred = seq(-4, 4),   y_true = 0,   n_points = 5000L  # higher resolution for smooth curves ) vis_combined$plot()

title: Visualization of Loss Functions
text: visualize classification loss functions, y_pred contains y*f(x)y * f(x):

title: Visualization of Loss Functions
text: can also define visualize custom loss functions:
code: custom_loss <- LossFunction$new(   id = "custom_loss",   label = "Sinusoidal-Exponential Loss",   task_type = "regr",   fun = function(r) abs(r) * exp(-abs(r) / 3) + 0.5 * sin(2 * r) )  vis <- as_visualizer(custom_loss, y_pred = seq(-10, 10), y_true = 0, n_points = 5000L) vis$plot()

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: Let’s define loss linear model iris data target Sepal.Width feature Petal.Width. First, Objective requires function evaluation: fix loss data, Ojbective$new() call allows pass custom arguments stored reused every call $eval() evaluate fun. , calling $eval(x) internally calls fun(x, ...). arguments must specified just : Visualize lm Objective:  can add also add points ggplot2 object  plotly object.
code: # Define the linear model loss function as SSE: l2norm <- function(x) sqrt(sum(crossprod(x)))  mylm <- function(x, Xmat, y) {   l2norm(y - Xmat %*% x) } # Use the iris dataset with response `Sepal.Width` and feature `Petal.Width`: Xmat <- model.matrix(~Petal.Width, data = iris) y <- iris$Sepal.Width  # Create a new object: obj_lm <- Objective$new(id = "iris LM", fun = mylm, xdim = 2, Xmat = Xmat, y = y, minimize = TRUE)  obj_lm$evalStore(c(1, 2)) obj_lm$evalStore(c(2, 3)) obj_lm$evalStore(coef(lm(Sepal.Width ~ Petal.Width, data = iris)))  obj_lm$archive #>                        x      fval                      grad        gnorm #>                   <list>     <num>                    <list>        <num> #> 1:                   1,2 21.553654        2.375467,11.722838 1.196109e+01 #> 2:                   2,3 43.410022        8.779078,16.929270 1.907020e+01 #> 3:  3.3084256,-0.2093598  4.951004 4.832272e-07,2.664535e-07 5.518206e-07 viz_lm <- as_visualizer(obj_lm, x1_limits = c(-0.5, 5), x2_limits = c(-3.2, 2.8)) viz_lm$plot() library(ggplot2)  archive_data <- data.frame(   x = sapply(obj_lm$archive$x, function(x) x[1]),   y = sapply(obj_lm$archive$x, function(x) x[2]) )  viz_lm$plot() + ggplot2::geom_point(   data = archive_data, aes(x = x, y = y),   color = "red", size = 2, inherit.aes = FALSE ) viz_lm <- as_visualizer(obj_lm, x1_limits = c(-0.5, 5), x2_limits = c(-3.2, 2.8), type = "surface") viz_lm$plot() %>% add_trace(x = archive_data$x, y = archive_data$y, z = obj_lm$archive$fval, type = "scatter3d", mode = "markers")

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: optimizer class defines optimization strategy initialized taking objective function, start value, learning rate. Available optimizer : Gradient descent OptimizerGD Momentum OptimizerMomentum Nesterovs momentum OptimizerNAG Creating optimizer done (let’s use x value works well): value set, optimization done calling $optimize() number steps argument: Calling $optimize() also writes archive optimizer also calls $evalStore() objective. Therefore, $optimize() writes two archives: can let algorithm run another 10 iterations second batch: Still satisfying.
code:
obj_banana <- obj("TF_banana") opt <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = c(0.8, 0.6), lr = 0.01) opt$optimize(10L) #> TF_banana: Batch 1 step 1: f(x) = 0.1572, x = c(0.7352, 0.5778) #> TF_banana: title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: layer Visualizer class $add_optimization_trace() gets optimizer argument adds optimization trace plot:

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: calling $optimize(), second argument stepSizeControl allows expand compress update added old value xx. example, GD xnew=xold+lr*Δf(xold)x_{\text{new}} = x_{\text{old}} + lr * \Delta_f(x_{\text{old}}) update u=lr*Δf(xold)u = lr * \Delta_f(x_{\text{old}}) multiplied return value stepSizeControl(). pre-implemented control functions like line search various decaying methods: stepSizeControlLineSearch(lower, upper): Conduct line search aa xnew=xold+*lr*Δf(xold)x_{\text{new}} = x_{\text{old}} +  * lr * \Delta_f(x_{\text{old}})`. stepSizeControlDecayTime(decay): Lower updates (1+decay*iteration)−1(1 + decay * iteration)^{-1}. stepSizeControlDecayExp(decay): Lower updates exp(−decay*iteration)exp(-decay * iteration). stepSizeControlDecayLinear(iter_zero): Lower updates iter_zero reached. Updates iter > iter_zero 0. stepSizeControlDecaySteps(drop_rate, every_iter): Lower updates every_iter drop_rate. Note functions return function contains function required signature: Let’s define multiple gradient descent optimizers optimize 100 steps step size control: now don’t know well worked. Let’s collect archives mergeOptimArchives() visualize step sizes function values patchwork magic:  Visualizing traces done adding optimization trace layer. can optimizers add multiple traces plot (colors picked randomly, see Visualizer section details plotting): Practically, issue also combine multiple control functions. important thing keep signature function allowing function get arguments x (current value), u (current update), obj (Objective object), opt (Optimizer object):
code:
stepSizeControlDecayTime() #> function (x, u, obj, opt)  #> { #>     assertStepSizeControl(x, u, obj, opt) #>     epoch <- nrow(obj$archive) #>     return(1/(1 + decay * epoch)) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x55d48ddc9b38> #> <environment: 0x55d48ddccee8> x0 <- c(0.8, 0.6) lr <- 0.01 obj_banana <- obj("TF_banana")  oo1 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD without LR Control", print_trace = FALSE) oo2 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD with Line Search", print_trace = FALSE) oo3 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD with Time Decay", print_trace = FALSE) oo4 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD with Exp Decay", print_trace = FALSE) oo5 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD with Linear Decay", print_trace = FALSE) oo6 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD with Step Decay", print_trace = FALSE)  oo1$optimize(steps = 100) oo2$optimize(steps = 100, stepSizeControlLineSearch()) oo3$optimize(steps = 100, stepSizeControlDecayTime()) oo4$optimize(steps = 100, stepSizeControlDecayExp()) oo5$optimize(steps = 100, stepSizeControlDecayLinear()) oo6$optimize(steps = 100, stepSizeControlDecaySteps()) arx <- mergeOptimArchives(oo1, oo2, oo3, oo4, oo5, oo6)  library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) gg1 <- ggplot(arx, aes(x = iteration, y = step_size, color = optim_id)) gg2 <- ggplot(arx, aes(x = iteration, y = fval_out, color = optim_id))  (gg1 + ggtitle("Step sizes") |   gg1 + ylim(0, 1) + ggtitle("Step sizes (zoomed)") |   gg2 + ggtitle("Objective")) +   plot_layout(guides = "collect") &   geom_line() &   theme_minimal() &   theme(legend.position = "bottom") &   ggsci::scale_color_simpsons() viz <- as_visualizer(obj_banana, type = "surface")  viz$add_optimization_trace(oo1) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo2) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo3) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo4) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo5) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo6)  viz$plot() myStepSizeControl <- function(x, u, obj, opt) {   sc1 <- stepSizeControlLineSearch(0, 10)   sc2 <- stepSizeControlDecayTime(0.1)   return(sc1(x, u, obj, opt) * sc2(x, u, obj, opt)) }  my_oo <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_banana, x_start = x0, lr = lr, id = "GD without LR Control", print_trace = FALSE) my_oo$optimize(100, myStepSizeControl) tail(my_oo$archive) title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: Visualizer class initialized calling as_visualizer(obj) given Objective. function automatically selects appropriate visualization type: 1D objectives: Uses Visualizer1DObj ggplot2 2D objectives: Uses Visualizer2DObj ggplot2 default, VisualizerSurfaceObj plotly type = "surface" specified interactive surface/contour plots arguments x1_limits x2_limits well padding stretch limits factor n_points specify number generated point per dimension, hence n_points^2 points evaluated create initial layers.

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: surface visualizations (plotly-based), initial layer always required layers (optimization traces) added step step. two available base layers contour lines $init_layer_contour() $init_layer_surface(). , first argument opacity second colorscale: Internally, add_trace() plotly called. arguments directly passed . contours parameter allows specify custom contour lines x, y, z axes: Alternatively, using ggplot2 backend:  customization can done modifying returned ggplot object:
code: viz <- as_visualizer(obj("TF_franke"), type = "surface") viz$init_layer_contour(colorscale = list(c(0, 1), c("white", "blue"))) viz$plot() viz <- as_visualizer(obj("TF_franke"), type = "surface") viz$init_layer_surface(opacity = 1, colorscale = list(c(0, 1), c("white", "black"))) viz$plot() viz <- as_visualizer(obj("TF_franke"), type = "surface") llower <- viz$objective$limits_lower lupper <- viz$objective$limits_upper ssize <- (lupper - llower) / 10 viz$init_layer_surface(   opacity = 1,   colorscale = list(c(0, 1), c("white", "black")),   contours = list(     x = list(show = TRUE, start = llower[1], end = lupper[1], size = ssize[1], color = "red"),     y = list(show = TRUE, start = llower[2], end = lupper[2], size = ssize[2], color = "red")   ) ) viz$plot() viz <- as_visualizer(obj("TF_franke")) viz$plot() library(ggplot2)  viz <- as_visualizer(obj("TF_franke")) p <- viz$plot()  p + labs(title = "TF Franke Function")

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
text: shown previously, optimization traces can added $add_optimization_trace. Let’s optimize custom linear model objective three available optimizers: Alternatively, using ggplot2 backend:
code: # Reset the archive to have an empty objective: obj_lm$clearArchive()  oo1 <- OptimizerGD$new(obj_lm, x_start = c(0, -0.05), lr = 0.001, print_trace = FALSE) oo2 <- OptimizerMomentum$new(obj_lm, x_start = c(-0.05, 0), lr = 0.001, print_trace = FALSE) oo3 <- OptimizerNAG$new(obj_lm, x_start = c(0, 0), lr = 0.001, print_trace = FALSE)  oo1$optimize(steps = 100) oo2$optimize(steps = 100) oo3$optimize(steps = 100) viz <- as_visualizer(obj_lm, x1_limits = c(-0.5, 5), x2_limits = c(-3.2, 2.8), type = "surface")   viz$add_optimization_trace(oo1, add_marker_at = round(seq(1, 100, len = 10L))) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo2, add_marker_at = c(1, 50, 90), marker_shape = c("square", "diamond", "cross")) viz$add_optimization_trace(oo3, add_marker_at = 100, marker_shape = "diamond-open")  viz$plot() viz_2d <- as_visualizer(obj_lm, x1_limits = c(-0.5, 5), x2_limits = c(-3.2, 2.8))  viz_2d$add_optimization_trace(oo1,    line_color = "#1f77b4",    line_width = 1.5,   marker_size = 3,   add_marker_at = c(1, 25, 50, 75, 100),   name = "Gradient Descent" )  viz_2d$add_optimization_trace(oo2,    line_color = "#ff7f0e",    line_width = 1.5,   line_type = "dashed",   marker_size = 3,   marker_shape = 17,  # triangle   add_marker_at = c(1, 30, 60, 100),   name = "Momentum" )  viz_2d$add_optimization_trace(oo3,    line_color = "#2ca02c",    line_width = 1.5,   line_type = "dotted",   marker_size = 3,   marker_shape = 15,  # square   add_marker_at = c(1, 20, 40, 80, 100),   name = "Nesterov AG" )  viz_2d$plot()

title: Visualization of Objective Functions
code: obj <- obj("TF_banana") # Use surface visualizer for surface features like surface, taylor, and hessian layers viz <- as_visualizer(obj, type = "surface") viz$init_layer_surface()  x0 <- c(0.85, 0.47) viz$add_layer_taylor(x0, npoints_per_dim = 5, degree = 1, x1margin = 0.3, x2margin = 0.3, contours = list(   x = list(show = TRUE, start = 0, end = 1, size = 0.03, color = "black"),   y = list(show = TRUE, start = 0, end = 1, size = 0.03, color = "black") )) viz$add_layer_hessian(x0) viz$plot()

what: Optional: Setup for Saving Plotly Plots
title: Visualize optimization methods
text: particular, $save() functionality surface plots uses plotly::save_image() internally, requires kaleido Python package. following instructions provided ?plotly::save_image assume miniconda installed already:
code: install.packages('reticulate') reticulate::install_miniconda() reticulate::conda_install('r-reticulate', 'python-kaleido') reticulate::conda_install('r-reticulate', 'plotly', channel = 'plotly') reticulate::use_miniconda('r-reticulate')

title: Visualize optimization methods
text: example shows visualize prediction surface SVM pima task included mlr3:  interactive exploration, can create surface visualizations plotly:  Save static version png:
code: library(vistool) library(mlr3verse) #> Loading required package: mlr3 # Create an example task, add missing data imputation and select 2 features task <- tsk("pima") task <- po("imputemean")$train(list(task))[[1]] task$select(c("insulin", "mass"))  # Select example learner learner <- lrn("classif.svm", predict_type = "prob")  # Create 2D ggplot2 visualization (default for 2-feature tasks) vis_2d <- as_visualizer(task, learner) # or explicitly: type = "2d" vis_2d$plot() # Create surface visualization for interactive plotly surface plot vis_surface <- as_visualizer(task, learner, type = "surface")  # Define a 3D scene vis_surface$set_scene(x = 1.4, y = 1.4, z = 1.4)  # View interactively vis_surface$plot() # only works if Python kaleido package is installed # see installation instructions above for setting up plotly save functionality vis_surface$save("man/figures/demo_1.png", width = 500, height = 500)

vistool 0.2.0
text: Switched ggplot2 visualization loss functions, model predictions objectives (2D, non-interactive); plotly implementation remains intact interactive surface visualizations (3D, type = "surface" as_visualizer()). as_visualizer() interface, save functions various things reworked match . Includes new loss functions (e.g., pinball loss); loss functions can now take arguments (e.g., quantile) combined one plot. Fixed numerous bugs surface visualizations, expanded corrected documentation. includes extensive testing suite (see tests/testthat), developer reference, updated vignettes.

title: vistool 0.1.0
text: Remove lim2002 optimizer ’s longer exported TestFunctions. Add GPL3 license line e.g. mlr3. Start versioning.
